central_thesis: The text introduces Chozzar as a primal Atlantean deity within the Draconian Tradition, elucidating his multifaceted symbolism connected to the Abyss, Daath, and the Qliphoth, and provides a structured invocation ritual for practitioners to connect with his current, explore the unconscious, and access Atlantean mysteries for initiatory transformation.

structure_content.summary: This section details Chozzar's identity as the God of Atlantean Magic, tracing his name's etymology ('pig'/'sow') to Typhonian zoomorphic symbols and linking him to Set and Hecate. His main symbol, the trident, connects him to Neptune/Poseidon and is identified as the true form of Chozzar by Kenneth Grant. The text draws parallels to Lovecraftian magic and Nodens, the God of the Deep. Within the Draconian Tradition, Chozzar is Lord of the Abyss and Atlantean mysteries, embodying both fiery (trident, Shin, Typhonian Gnosis, Shiva's Trident) and watery attributes. His lunar symbolism ties him to the feminine current (the sow consuming 'excrements' of the lunar cycle/menstrual blood). Chozzar is associated with the Qabalistic Abyss and Daath, a 'false' Sephira connecting Dayside and Nightside, with Grant suggesting a link to Choronzon as a guardian of the Abyss's entrance/exit.

structure_content.chapter_title: Invocation of the Lord of the Deep
structure_content.summary: This section provides a practical ritual for invoking Chozzar. It outlines the preparation of the altar, requiring Chozzar's sigil (drawn in gold on black), anointing the sigil with blood, and a chalice of water as sacrament. The practitioner is instructed to sit or stand comfortably, focus on the sigil while chanting Chozzar's name, envisioning the sigil as a gateway for his energy and presence. Once the temple is charged, the invocation proceeds by drawing the trident symbol in the air with a ritual blade, envisioning it burning with Draconian Current flames, and reciting a specific call to Chozzar. The ritual concludes with drinking the sacrament and merging consciousness with Chozzar, focusing on the Third Eye to receive visions and allow them to flow freely. Visions may include Chozzar's various forms (human-fish/snake, monstrous, black/sea-green energy) and realms (dark underwater temples, black pyramids/obelisks, scenes of war), with messages about resolving conflict by reaching its source.

This section explicitly presents the visual representation of the Draconian Sigil of Chozzar, which is a key tool in the invocation ritual described in the preceding section. It serves as a focal point and gateway for establishing contact with the deity.

key_concepts.definition: The God of Atlantean Magic, Lord of the Deep, associated with the Abyss and Qliphoth in the Draconian Tradition. Symbolized by the trident and the sow/pig (Typhonian zoomorphic symbols). Embodies both fiery and watery currents, and a feminine lunar current. Linked to Neptune, Poseidon, and potentially Choronzon.
A specific magical system that incorporates Chozzar as a deity, focusing on the exploration of Atlantean mysteries and the Abyss as part of an initiatory process towards the Qliphoth.

Chozzar's primary symbol, a fiery emblem associated with the letter Shin, the triple fire-tongue of Typhonian Gnosis, and Shiva's Trident (representing creation, maintenance, destruction). It serves as a tool for 'separation of waters' or planes, enabling passage between worlds and dimensions.

A foundational concept in the Draconian Tradition and Qabalistic Tree, 'the Deep,' representing the unconscious mind and a realm associated with Chozzar. It is accessed via Daath and serves as an entry/exit point to the Nightside and Qliphoth.

The 'Tree of Nightside' in Qabalistic esotericism, representing hidden or shadow aspects of creation. Chozzar is an 'excellent guide' for exploring the 'hidden layers of the Self' within the initiatory process of the Qliphoth.

A specific esoteric knowledge system, implicitly linked to Kenneth Grant's work. It is referenced in relation to the 'triple fire-tongue' of the trident and the Typhonian zoomorphic symbols connected to Chozzar.

Ancient, often esoteric, knowledge and realms attributed to the lost civilization of Atlantis. Chozzar is depicted as the Lord presiding over these mysteries, and his invocation aims to open 'the gates to the lost realms of Atlantis'.
The 'false' Sephira on the Qabalistic Tree, located in the Abyss, connecting the realms of the Dayside (Sephiroth) with the Nightside (Qliphoth). Chozzar is a god-form associated with this gateway.

practical_system.description: The practical system presented is a direct invocation ritual for Chozzar, the Lord of the Deep, designed to facilitate a profound connection with his primal Atlantean current. The core mechanics involve creating a dedicated ritual space with specific tools, using focused intent and vibrational keys (chanting Chozzar's name), symbolic actions (anointing sigil with blood, drawing trident in air), and a spoken invocation. The goal is to open gateways to his realm, allow his energies to flow into the practitioner's consciousness, and induce visions that guide exploration of the unconscious (the 'Deep') and Atlantean mysteries, leading to personal transformation within the Qliphothic path.
tools: Sigil of Chozzar (gold on black surface)
Ritual blade (for drawing trident symbol in air)
rituals: Invocation of Chozzar, Lord of the Deep

relevant_quotes.text: The name "Chozzar" means "pig," or "sow,‚Äù which is one of the Typhonian zoomorphic symbols of Set, associated also with Hecate and her power of transforming men into beasts.
In the Draconian Tradition, Chozzar is one of the deities associated with the Abyss, and as the lord of the trident, he has significance in exploration of the Atlantean mysteries.

His trident is a fiery symbol, associated with the letter Shin and the triple fire-tongue of Typhonian gnosis, denoting the Trident of Shiva, which is both a weapon and the emblem of creation, maintenance, and destruction.
Chozzar is also one of the god-forms associated with the Abyss on the Qabalistic Tree and the Gate of Daath, the "false" Sephira that connects the realms of the Dayside with the Nightside.
He speaks of the trident being a tool of separation - separating "waters," or planes, thus making the passage through worlds and dimensions possible.
As the Lord of "the Deep," meaning "the unconscious," he is an excellent guide into the hidden layers of the Self in the initiatory process of the Qliphoth.
I, (your magical name), open the Gates of the Nightside, And I invoke Chozzar, God of Atlantean Magic, To come to my temple and manifest!
Reveal to me the power of the trident So that I may rule the great ocean of Infinity And open the gates to the lost realms of Atlantis!

critical_analysis.relevance: This text is highly relevant within contemporary Western Esotericism, particularly for practitioners of Draconian Magic, Qliphothic work, and those exploring Typhonian currents. It seamlessly integrates distinct occult concepts: Kenneth Grant's Typhonian Gnosis (linking Chozzar to Set, Hecate, and potentially Choronzon), Qabalistic frameworks (Abyss, Daath, Qliphoth), and classic Atlantean themes. Its unique contribution lies in positing Chozzar as a nexus for these disparate currents, offering a distinct path for exploring the deep unconscious and ancestral/magical 'lost' realms. The emphasis on the trident as a tool for inter-dimensional separation and the integration of feminine lunar symbolism into a primal 'Lord of the Deep' archetype enriches the existing magical discourse, providing specific operative methodologies for profound self-transformation and gnosis.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience is experienced practitioners of the Draconian Tradition, advanced occultists engaged in Qliphothic exploration, or those with a foundational understanding of Chaos Magic, Kenneth Grant's works, and advanced ceremonial magic. The concepts discussed (Abyss, Daath, Qliphoth, Typhonian Gnosis) are not introductory, and the ritual's intensity (e.g., blood anointing, direct invocation of primal forces) suggests a need for prior experience and spiritual maturity. It is designed for magicians seeking deep initiatory experiences, exploration of the unconscious, and access to chthonic or 'Atlantean' magical currents.
